Goal: Compare a list of desired skills, knowledge, and qualifications for an Instructional Designer with a job description for an Instructional Designer position found on LinkedIn Jobs.

Desired Output: A report indicating whether each item on the list of desired skills, knowledge, and qualifications for an Instructional Designer is present in the job description for an Instructional Designer position found on LinkedIn Jobs. If a list item is present in the job description, add the list item number from the provided list of desired skills, knowledge, and qualifications, a "MATCH" indication next to the relevant item in the report along with quotes from the job description that verify the match. If a list item is not present in the job description, don't include this item in the report.

Inputs:

A list of desired skills, knowledge, and qualifications for an Instructional Designer.
A job description for an Instructional Designer position found on LinkedIn Jobs.
Method: Comparison of the list of desired skills, knowledge, and qualifications with the job description found on LinkedIn Jobs.

List of desired skills, knowledge, and qualifications:
"1. Instructional design models & principles (e.g. ADDIE, Dick and Carey) 
2. adult learning theory 
3. Organizational development
4. Accessing and analyzing DATA 
5. Theories of leadership 
6. Gamification
7. Blended learning techniques 
8. Formative and summative evaluation
9. AR/VR Environments
10. Agile methodology (e.g. Scrum) 
11. Interface design 
12. Classroom-based technology integration techniques 
13. Human resources management
14. Professional development 
15. Customer service
16. Motivation theories (e.g. ARCS) 
17. Markup languages (e.g. HTML/XHTML/XML)
18. Assessment methods (e.g. criterion-referenced)
19. Online/blended programme management 
20. Instructional simulation and game design 
21. 3D modelling tools (e.g. Maya) 
22. SWOT analysis 
23. Project management software (e.g. Microsoft Project) 
24. Learning object standards (e.g. SCORM)
25. Laws, policies and procedures in training programmes 
26. Cloud technologies 
27. Business intelligence (e.g. SAP BW)
28. Programming languages (e.g. C++) 
29. Cascading Style Sheets (CSS)
30. Social media technologies (e.g. Twitter)
31. Web design principles 
32. Assessment software (e.g. Respondus)
33. Audio software (e.g. Audacity) 
34. Streaming video technology (e.g. Windows Media Server)
35. Project management principles (e.g. PMBOK) 
36. Industry Standard 
37. Virtual classrooms (e.g. Wimba or Elluminate! Live)
38. Virtual environments (e.g. SecondLife) 
39. Cognitive learning theory (e.g. Cognitive Load Theory) 
40. Constructivism
41. Mobile learning platforms (e.g. Android) 
42. Synchronous distance learning methodologies (e.g. Blackboard Collaborate) 
43. Human Performance Technology principles
44. Flipped classroom (blended) 
45. Mobile application development
46. Desktop publishing software (e.g. PageMaker) 
47. Web authoring tools (e.g. Dreamweaver) 
48. Operating system software (e.g. Windows 7) 
49. Game engines (e.g. Unity) 
50. Copyright laws
51. Web 2.0 technology (e.g. Wikis, Blogs, Podcasts, etc.) 
52. Accessibility software (e.g. JAWS) 
53. Six Sigma
54. Common Core State Standards (CCSS) 
55. College/university administration 
56. Twenty-first-century skills frameworks (e.g. P21)".

Job description from LinkedIn:
"Our client, a prestigious Ivy League university, is actively looking for an Instructional Designer to join their team in Boston! This role is hybrid so local candidates are required. This is a 6 month initial contract with the opportunity to extend or convert\*\*\* This Instructional Designer will be responsible for working closely with faculty or business subject matter experts to design, create, and deliver online, blended and instructor-led classroom training courses and documentation using principles and practices of instructional design and adult learning theory. Responsibilities Develop content for learning or knowledge management systems Conduct learning and business needs analysis Draft expected learning outcomes that align with course goals; determine scope and sequence of content, identify impacted or target audiences and relevant pre-requisites for learner success, design/implement course evaluation plans Devise modes of assessment to measure the effectiveness of the course Write effective copy, instructional materials, and audio/video scrips to help participants meet learning objectives Produce learning materials in a variety of formats including print, graphics, audio, video, and multimedia Use e-learning authoring tools to upload instructional content to websites, e-learning platforms, or learning management systems May develop and deliver train-the trainer programs, and deliver in-person instruction of complex information to participants Provide training on instructional technologies and tools Required Skills & Experience Master’s degree, formal training or certification in Instructional Design is preferable 3-5 years of professional experience in Instructional Design or Development Demonstrated experience with common web and multimedia authoring tools (such as Adobe Captivate, Articulate Storyline, and Camtasia) and knowledge of HTML is required Strong communication skills are required"

Report:

1. MATCH: "This Instructional Designer will be responsible for working closely with faculty or business subject matter experts to design, create, and deliver online, blended and instructor-led classroom training courses and documentation using principles and practices of instructional design and adult learning theory." (Item 1 and 2)
2. MATCH: "Conduct learning and business needs analysis" (Item 3)
3. MATCH: "Devise modes of assessment to measure the effectiveness of the course" (Item 8)
4. MATCH: "Write effective copy, instructional materials, and audio/video scrips to help participants meet learning objectives" (Item 12)
5. MATCH: "Use e-learning authoring tools to upload instructional content to websites, e-learning platforms, or learning management systems" (Item 47)

Note: Items 3, 4, 6, 9-11, 13-15, 16, 18-22, 25-26, 28-29, 31-36, 38-41, 44-50, 52-54 and 56 were not found in the job description.
